conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to block non-medical features during caregiver work hours, which includes detailed health check-in guidance, while User Story B wants ALFRED to explain all health check-in steps in detail at any time. These opposing instructions on the same feature during the same period create a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-medical features during my work hours so I can focus only on clinical tasks without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to explain all health check-in steps in detail so I can learn and manage my health well.
resolutionDescription: Adjust User Story A to block only non-medical features unrelated to health check-in during caregiver hours, and update User Story B to receive detailed health check-in explanations only outside caregiver work hours or upon user request.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-medical features except health check-in guidance during my work hours to focus on clinical tasks.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to explain health check-in steps in detail when caregivers are not working or when I ask, so I can manage my health well.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-medical features during caregiver work hours, which could include hard exercises. User Story B wants to allow hard exercises without postponing them after health check-ins. This creates opposite instructions about allowing or blocking hard exercises after check-ins.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-medical features during my work hours so I can focus only on clinical tasks without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to challenge myself with hard exercises and do not want to postpone them after health check-ins.
resolutionDescription: Modify the caregiver's story to block only non-medical features that are distractions but allow hard exercises during work hours if they are safe; update the older adult's story to accept hard exercises are allowed but may be adjusted based on caregiver's clinical priorities.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block distracting non-medical features during my work hours, but allow safe hard exercises to support clinical care.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to do hard exercises without delays, while respecting caregiver's health checks and safety recommendations.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to block non-medical features during caregiver work hours, while User Story B wants ALFRED to offer help automatically at home, which may include non-medical features. These opposite instructions for system behavior during the same time can conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-medical features during my work hours so I can focus only on clinical tasks without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to offer help automatically at home with my permission, so I stay healthy and feel safe.
resolutionDescription: We specify time and permission conditions to avoid conflict: non-medical features are blocked only during caregiver work hours, but ALFRED can offer help including non-medical features automatically outside those hours with user permission.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-medical features during my work hours to focus on clinical tasks without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want ALFRED to offer help automatically at home outside caregiver work hours with my permission, so I stay healthy and feel safe.

conflictDescription: One story requires video check-ins only at the hospital, while the other wants video calls for exercise challenges that can happen anywhere. These are conflicting conditions for when and where video calls should occur.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want video check-ins only at my hospital, so I can keep my work clear and focused.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enjoy video calls that challenge me with hard exercises, so I stay motivated and active.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to clarify that video calls for exercise challenges can happen anywhere, while video check-ins for caregivers are limited to the hospital. This separation resolves the conflicting conditions by defining distinct contexts for video calls.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want video check-ins limited to the hospital, so I can keep my work clear and focused.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enjoy video calls for exercise challenges anywhere, so I stay motivated and active.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants to block non-medical features during work hours (operation: block features), while the older adult expects to have control over health check-ins only at home arranged by themselves (operation: allow health check-ins). These operations conflict because blocking features during work could include health check-ins, contradicting the older adult's request.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-medical features during my work hours to focus on clinical tasks without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want health check-ins only at my home and arranged by me, so I feel safe and avoid hospitals.

conflictDescription: The medical caregiver wants ALFRED to block non-medical features during work hours, which may include therapy sessions, while the older adult wants to join therapy sessions only when they ask. These requirements oppose each other on controlling therapy participation during the same time period.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-medical features during my work hours to focus on clinical tasks without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to join therapy sessions only when I ask, so that I keep full control and feel safe about my recovery.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to send medication reminders automatically when allowed, while User Story B requires that reminders only start when the older adult says so, forbidding automatic start without user initiation. These two impose opposite expectations on when reminders should start.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enable medication reminders when I say, so I avoid unwanted alerts and keep control.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and timing, while User Story B requires the user to respond shortly to reminders to keep control and avoid long talks, which may conflict if the system tries to enforce reminders strictly but the user wants minimal interaction.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to respond shortly to medication reminders to keep control and avoid long talks.

conflictDescription: The medical caregiver wants ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, which implies controlled and possibly less frequent reminders to avoid stress. The older adult wants frequent exercise and health check reminders that they can adjust, implying a higher or more persistent reminder frequency. These requirements conflict on how often reminders should be sent.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often to do exercises and health checks, allowing me to adjust difficulty to stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires reminders to be sent only when allowed and adjusted in strength, while User Story B wants ALFRED to suggest rest after hard exercises. The triggering events for ALFRED's reminders differ and may cause inconsistent timing or conditions for reminders within the same cluster.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to suggest short rest times after hard exercises, so I can recover and stay challenged.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants reminders that adjust in strength and happen only when allowed to avoid stress, while User Story B wants spontaneous surprise exercise challenges that may act like unplanned reminders. This creates opposite expectations on when and how reminders or prompts should happen.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to offer occasional surprise exercise challenges, so I stay motivated and improve strength.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to send medication reminders automatically with adjusted strength and only when allowed, enforcing reminders. User Story B wants the older person to freely choose exercise time, implying control over scheduling and no enforced reminders. These impose opposite expectations on system behavior regarding automatic reminders and user control.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to choose my exercise time freely so I feel in control and motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to send medication reminders automatically and adjust their strength, which implies starting reminders at system decision times. User Story B requires the older adult to choose when to start exercises, implying forbidding automatic start of these reminders or prompts. These two impose opposite behaviors on timing control of reminders or prompts.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to send medication reminders that adjust in strength and only when allowed, so patients take medicine on time without stress.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to choose when to start exercises to keep control and stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to set exercise goals with adjustable difficulty, implying system control on exercise settings, while User Story B wants to enable medication reminders only when the older adult says, showing user control over activation. Both want control over reminders or goals, but one wants system-driven settings and the other wants user-driven activation, which can conflict in managing reminders.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise goals with adjustable difficulty, so patients get safe and effective care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enable medication reminders when I say, so I avoid unwanted alerts and keep control.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to set exercise goals with adjustable difficulty to ensure safety, implying control over exercise intensity, while User Story B wants to respond shortly to medication reminders to avoid long talks, implying minimal interaction. These impose opposite expectations about user engagement and control in reminders within the same cluster.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to set exercise goals with adjustable difficulty, so patients get safe and effective care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to respond shortly to medication reminders to keep control and avoid long talks.

conflictDescription: User Story A asks ALFRED to start medication reminders gently and increase their strength if needed. User Story B asks ALFRED to start medication reminders only when the older adult says so, effectively forbidding automatic or unsolicited reminders. These two stories have opposite expectations about when reminders should start.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to enable medication reminders when I say, so I avoid unwanted alerts and keep control.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to start and increase medication reminders if needed, while User Story B wants to respond shortly to reminders to keep control and avoid long talks, implying a desire to limit or stop reminder interactions. These impose opposite expectations on how reminders and responses should be handled.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to respond shortly to medication reminders to keep control and avoid long talks.

conflictDescription: The informal caregiver wants medication reminders that start gentle and increase only if needed, implying a controlled frequency. The older adult wants frequent exercise reminders with adjustable difficulty, indicating a higher and adjustable reminder frequency. These differing expectations on how often reminders occur create a conflict about reminder frequency.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often to do exercises and health checks, allowing me to adjust difficulty to stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A asks ALFRED to provide medication reminders that get stronger if needed, while User Story B asks ALFRED to suggest rest times after hard exercises. These two requirements trigger different operations based on different events (medication time vs. exercise recovery), which may cause conflicting timing or priority in reminders.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to suggest short rest times after hard exercises, so I can recover and stay challenged.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to give gentle medication reminders that increase if needed, while User Story B wants ALFRED to provide surprise exercise challenges occasionally. Both involve prompting the user, but the gentle reminders and surprise challenges may conflict in how and when ALFRED starts these prompts under the same triggering context.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to offer occasional surprise exercise challenges, so I stay motivated and improve strength.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to start medication reminders that increase in strength if needed, while User Story B wants the older person to freely choose exercise time, implying the system should not start reminders at fixed times without user control. This creates opposite expectations on when reminders (operations) should start.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to choose my exercise time freely so I feel in control and motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to start medication reminders that get stronger if needed, while User Story B wants to choose when to start exercises, implying control over timing. This creates opposite expectations about when reminders or prompts should start, causing a conflict about system-initiated timing versus user-controlled timing.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to choose when to start exercises to keep control and stay motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to provide medication reminders that become stronger if needed, while User Story B wants to freely decide when and how reminders are set, which may forbid automatic strengthening of reminders. These are opposite expectations on reminder management.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to freely decide when and how to set reminders for my health appointments, so I feel in control and not pressured.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants reminders that start gentle and become stronger only if needed, while User Story B wants frequent reminders. These impose different expectations on how often and how strong reminders should be, which may conflict in frequency and intensity.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to remind me often and support my health with gentle guidance, so I keep my independence.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to send medication reminders that can get stronger if needed, while User Story B forbids reminders to be sent unless the older adult allows. These instructions are opposite for the same event of sending reminders.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to provide gentle medication reminders that can become stronger if needed, so clients stay healthy and feel comfortable.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to send exercise reminders only when I allow, so I keep control over my activities.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-urgent notifications only during caregiver work hours, allowing urgent alerts at any time, while User Story B wants urgent notifications to caregivers to be sent immediately without delay. These create conflicting event conditions about when urgent notifications should be sent to caregivers.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-urgent notifications during my work hours but allow urgent alerts to avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want caregivers to get urgent notifications right away, so they can help me quickly when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants controlled access to patient health data only in emergencies, implying restrictions, while User Story B wants to share most health data freely with the caregiver. This shows opposite expectations about data sharing control under the same condition.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want controlled access to patient health data in emergencies to provide fast and effective care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share most health data freely with my informal caregiver, so I feel supported while keeping some privacy control.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants the system to allow controlled access to patient health data in emergencies, while User Story B requires data to be shared only with medical staff when the older person agrees. These two conflict because emergency access may happen without prior consent, which forbids access in all cases.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want controlled access to patient health data in emergencies to provide fast and effective care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want my health data shared with medical staff when I agree, to get good care.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants fast access to patient data when authorized, while the older adult wants to share only most data freely, keeping some privacy control. This creates a conflict because one requires quick full access, and the other forbids sharing all data without control.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to access patient data quickly when authorized, so I can provide timely care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share most health data freely with my informal caregiver, so I feel supported while keeping some privacy control.

conflictDescription: The medical caregiver wants to access patient data quickly when authorized, but the older person requires data sharing only when they agree. These create different triggering conditions for data access, which can conflict if immediate access is needed but user consent is not yet given.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to access patient data quickly when authorized, so I can provide timely care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want my health data shared with medical staff when I agree, to get good care.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all clinical actions, while User Story B requires health data to be shared only during scheduled video calls and by the older adult's choice, implying selective sharing. This creates opposite expectations on data logging and sharing behavior.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to share my health data during scheduled video calls, so my family knows how I am doing when I choose.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants clear and professional communication to save time and avoid distractions, while the older adult wants to share health data during video calls at their choice, which may introduce communication styles and timing that do not align. These different conditions for communication could conflict when both try to happen at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to communicate clearly and professionally with patients to save time and avoid distractions during my shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to share my health data during scheduled video calls, so my family knows how I am doing when I choose.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires video calls only with client consent, forbidding calls without permission, while User Story B expects sharing health data during scheduled video calls that the older adult chooses. If the caregiver plans calls without consent, it conflicts with the older adult's control over sharing data.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to plan video calls only with client consent, so I respect their preferences and support them.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to share my health data during scheduled video calls, so my family knows how I am doing when I choose.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires video calls to be scheduled at times chosen by the older adult for comfort, while User Story B requires sharing health data during scheduled video calls, which may impose different timing or conditions on when health data can be shared. These differing conditions for scheduling and data sharing events may conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to invite clients to video calls at times they choose, so they feel comfortable and engaged without pressure.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to share my health data during scheduled video calls, so my family knows how I am doing when I choose.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants to play games to support care and emotional connection, implying interactive, possibly gentle activities, while the older adult wants harder exercises for self-challenge and motivation, implying more intense physical activity. These goals suggest different operation intensities and frequencies that may conflict in the system's activity recommendations.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver I want to play games with my clients to help us connect and support their care.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult I want to do harder exercises to challenge myself and stay strong and motivated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to play care games together with clients, implying joint or possibly gentle interaction, while User Story B wants more difficult exercises to challenge themselves, which may require different intensity or frequency. These differing expectations on exercise difficulty and interaction frequency can cause conflict in how the system schedules or offers exercise activities.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to play games with my clients to help us connect and support their care together.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult I want to do harder exercises to challenge myself and stay strong and motivated.

conflictDescription: The caregiver wants to organize and limit care tasks to avoid overload, which suggests controlling the frequency and amount of tasks. The older adult wants to do harder exercises more often to stay motivated and strong, which may increase task frequency. These goals conflict on how often physical tasks should be done.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to organize and choose care tasks for many clients, so that I can avoid overload and give better help.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult I want to do harder exercises to challenge myself and stay strong and motivated.
